summary: steroid-induced osteonecrosis of the femoral head (ONFH) is the most common clinical nontraumatic ONFH. the matrix metalloproteinase/tissue inhibitor of metalloproteinase (MMP/TIMP) system was found to play a significant role in the development of ONFH. genetic variants of MMP8 contribute to steroid-induced ONFH susceptibility. steroid-induced ONFH occurs in 39% of patients with severe acute respiratory syndrome within a few months of treatment with glucocorticoid therapy. a family of zinc-dependent proteolytic enzymes are expressed by stromal cells, infiltrating inflammatory cells, cancer cells, and osteoclasts. MMPs play central roles in morphogenesis, wound healing, tissue repair, and remodeling in response to injury. study aims to determine the relationship between genetic polymorphisms of the TIMP/MMP system and the risk of steroid-induced ONFH. study participants A total of 285 patients with steroid-induced ONFH were recruited between September 2014 and January 2016 at Zhengzhou Traditional Chinese Medicine Traumatology Hospital. individuals with excessive use of corticosteroids, alcohol consumption, or significant familial hereditary disease were excluded. our study protocol adhered to the principles of the Declaration of Helsinki. polymorphisms and the risk of steroid-induced ONFH were evaluated under different genetic models. a total of 285 patients were recruited between cases and controls were calculated by chi-squared test/Fisher exact test. association between genotype polymorphisms and risk of steroid-induced ONFH was evaluated under different genetic models.
